content.subheader: Partly due to police presence in school, youth have a 26.8% of getting arrested.
content.resultCopy: As a young black man, your odds of success are odd indeed. Try your luck navigating the stats.
content.urlText: American Academy of Arts and Sciences

content.header: Since you've been arrested, will you graduate high school?
content.subheader: Students who have been arrested have on average a 40% likelihood of graduating high school
content.resultCopy: The same mistake is a suspension in one school, and an arrest in another.

content.header: High school's done, will you graduate college?
content.subheader: You conquered the first challenge, but college is a whole new monster.
content.resultCopy: Last year, Boston Public Schools celebrated their (highest-ever) graduation rate of 66%.
Too often, youth of color head to college woefully under-prepared
content.yes: if yes then yes then yes
content.no: if yes then yes then no

content.resultCopy: Too often, youth of color head to college woefully under-prepared

content.no: if yes then yes then no

content.subheader: As a high school dropout, your likelihood of imprisonment skyrockets to 68% percent.
content.resultCopy: Last year, Boston Public Schools celebrated their (highest-ever) graduation rate of 66%.
content.urlText: American Academy of Arts and Sciences

content.resultHeader: You've been arrested and sent to prison.
content.resultCopy: Not only do you have a tough path ahead of you, but you've set the bar for your kids. Studies show that children of offenders are five times more likely than their peers to end up in prison themselves. One in 10 will have been incarcerated before reaching adulthood.

content.resultHeader: You don't go to prison, but you have your work cut out for you.
content.resultCopy: As a high school dropout, there's about a 30 percent likelihood that you will end up living below the poverty line. There's a 12% likelihood that your kids will be gang involved, and a 20% likelihood that they'll be arrested and charged for an adult crime by age 24.

content.subheader: Since you haven't been arrested, statistically, you have a 81% likelihood of graduating high school.
content.resultCopy: The same mistake is a suspension in one school, and an arrest in another.
